_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Springdale Ice Cream and Beverage
Ammonia PSM System
Executive Summary

Springdale Ice Cream and Beverage (SICB), owned by the Kroger Company, manufactures ice cream and beverages.   An Ammonia (CAS# 7664-41-7) Refrigeration system is used at the facility to provide cooling and freezing capabilities.  The ammonia refrigeration system is regulated under OSHA PSM standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and is subjected to Program 3 requirements of the EPAA?s Risk Management Program.  SICB is strongly committed to employee, public, and environmental safety. This commitment is inherent to our comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers the following areas:

-Employee Participation
-Process Safety Information
-Process Hazard Analysis
-Operating Procedures
-Non-Routine Work Practices
-Contractor Requirements
-Process Safety Review
-Mechanical Integrity
-Training Requirements
-Management of Change
-Pre-Startup Safety Review
-Incident Investigation
-Emergency Planning and Response
-Compliance Audits
-Security Against Theft

It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances. Unforeseeably, if such a release does occur, our highly trained emergency response personnel are available to control and mitigate the effects of the release. We are also coordinated with the Springdale Fire Department and the Hamilton County LEPC for emergency response support.

Employee Participation:
Plant employees are kept informed of the PSM program by initial training upon hire and periodic refresher training in safety meetings and plant wide events.  The facilityA?s Refrigeration technicians are in charge of the administration and actual operation of the ammonia system.  All records of the PSM system are maintained in the PSM office located in the Engine Room of the facility, where they are open to examination at any time by concerned employees or management.

Process Safety Information:
Written information is available to the employees

so that they can identify and understand the potential hazards of the ammonia refrigeration system.  The written information includes the MSDS for ammonia and a description of the design of the ammonia refrigeration system.  An Emergency Response Summary book has been prepared and distributed to the Springdale Fire Department to help them to be prepared for an emergency response.

Process Hazard Analysis:
Our facility conducts comprehensive studies so that hazards associated with our ammonia refrigeration system are identified and controlled efficiently. The methodology used to carry out these analyses is What If/Checklist Technique. The studies are undertaken by a team of qualified personnel with expertise in refrigeration engineering and process operations, and are reevaluated at a minimum of every five (5) years.  Any findings related to the process hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.

Operating Procedures:
For the purpose of safely conducting activities related to our ammonia refrigeration system, SICB maintains written operating procedures. These procedures address various modes of operation including startup, normal operations, emergency operations, normal shutdown, and emergency shutdown. The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to all operators who work with the ammonia refrigeration system.

Training:
A program has been developed for training employees in all aspects of the refrigeration system.  Training for the refrigeration technicians includes a review of all duties they must perform on the ammonia refrigeration system.  The technician training program includes formal classroom training, on-the-job training, and performance demonstrations.

Contractors:
All contractors working on the system are screened and evaluated by the technicians in charge of the PSM program before being allowed to work on the ammonia refrigeration system.  Contractor work is constantly monitored by the Springdale technicians, who have complet

e authority to suspend the work of any contractor if it is not been done properly.

Pre-Startup Safety Review:
Pre-start up safety reviews are conducted any time the ammonia refrigeration system, or any of its components, is opened for repairs, tie-ins, or modifications. These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating procedures, and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

Mechanical Integrity:
SICB carries out well documented maintenance checks on ammonia refrigeration system equipment to provide proper operations. Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; pressure vessels, piping systems, pressure relief valves, emergency shutdown systems, controls and pumps.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in applicable maintenance practices. Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed. Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.

Hot Work Permit:
This element of the system requires that a signed permit is obtained before any cutting, welding, or open flame is used at the facility.

Management of Change:
Written procedures are in place at SICB to manage changes in ammonia systems technology, equipment, and procedures. Process operators, maintenance personnel, or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by an ammonia systems modification are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.

Incident Investigation:
SICB promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in, an unintentional release of ammonia. These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident, as well as any corrective actions implemented to prevent the release from reoccurring. All reports are retained for a minimum of five (5) years.

Compliance Audits:
SICB co

nducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented. These audits are carried out at least every three (3) years and any corrective actions required as a result of the audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.

System Security:
A system has been implemented to prevent theft or tampering with the ammonia system, including perimeter guarding, physical and electronic locks on critical equipment, and around-the-clock monitoring by operators and Security Personnel.

Five-Year Accident History:
Springdale Ice Cream & Beverage has had one accidental release of ammonia in the past five years.   This event occurred on June 14, 2010.  A total of 394 pounds of ammonia was released, causing evacuation of the facility.  This release occurred when a product mix tank air vent line was mistakenly capped after the tank was cleaned.  As a result, when the tank was filled with ice cream mix, the tank over pressurized and swelled.  This swelling caused the vessel to distort and split the outer metal shell.  The shell dropped on to the ammonia oil drain valve and piping located below the tank, causing the ammonia release.  The tank was removed from service and piping modifications have been installed that will prevent the vent line from being mistakenly capped in the future.  Four employees were treated and released at area hospitals.  No one off site was injured.  No off site evacuations were necessary.
